At racing associations where messengers are employed or telephone messages are used to deliver official pay-offs to the cashiers, "60 seconds after the pay-offs have been posted on the Public Board".

If, under the conditions set forth above, it is too late to correct the error, then the following rules shall apply: If the error results in an overpayment to the public, no subsequent correction is made. If the error results in an underpayment, the amount of the underpayment, after it has been determined, is added to the same pool of the next succeeding race. However, should an underpayment occur in the last race of any scheduled race meeting, the amount of the underpayment shall be paid over to the Commission for the account of the Maryland Horsemen's Assistance Fund, Inc.

The pay-off may be posted after the pool closes and before the race completing the double has been run. In the event of a dead heat in the first race of the daily double, posting of the pay-off prices may be deferred until the race completing the daily double has been run.

The daily double is not a parlay and has no connection with or relation to the mutuel betting. All prices on the daily double will be calculated in a separate pool. All tickets will be to win only (straight), except as otherwise provided in this regulation. A "field" may not be permitted in any race involved in the daily double.

If no ticket is sold combining the two winners, the daily double pool then shall be apportioned equally between those having tickets including the winner of the first half and those having tickets including the winner of the second half in the same manner in which a "place" pool is calculated.
If no ticket is sold including the winner of the first half, the entire pool shall be distributed to holders of tickets which include the winner of the second half.
If no ticket is sold including the winner of the second half, then the entire pool shall be distributed to holders of tickets which include the winner of the first half of the daily double.
If no ticket is sold including the winner of either half, then the pool shall be distributed to holders of tickets finishing second in the two races of the daily double.

If, for any reason, the first half of the daily double is cancelled and declared "no race", a full and complete refund shall be made of the daily double pool. If, for any reason, the second half of the daily double is declared "no race", the daily double pool shall be distributed to the holders of the tickets on the winner of the first half in the same manner as a straight pool.

If, after the first half of the daily double has been run and declared "official", a horse is scratched or excused from the second half of the daily double, then a consolation pay-off shall be made to holders of tickets which combine the winner of the first half and the scratched or excused horse. The consolation pay-off shall be calculated as follows:
The net daily double pool (gross pool less commission) shall be divided by the total number of tickets sold combining the winner of the first half;
The quotient thus obtained shall constitute the consolation pay-off to be paid to holders of each ticket combining the winner of the first half and the scratched or excused horse in the second half;
The entire consolation pool (number of eligible tickets times the consolation price), plus the breakage, shall then be deducted from the net daily double pool;
The remaining pool is the new net pool for the daily double.
If holders of tickets lose the first half of the daily double and the horse in the second half is scratched or excused, there will be no refund.
If no ticket is sold which would require distribution of the daily double pool, the association shall make a complete and full refund of the pool.

section.heading: Twin Doubles.
section.text: Associations licensed by the Commission to conduct harness racing meetings may, with the approval of the Commission, conduct a so-called twin double, subject to the following rules:

para.text: The twin double is a part of the pari-mutuel system of wagering. It is a contract by each participant to pick (select) the winner of each of four races as may be designated by a licensee, with the approval of the Commission. For the purpose of this rule, the four races will be referred to as the "twin double races." The first two races so designated shall be referred to as the first half of the twin double. The third and fourth races so designated shall hereafter be referred to as the second half of the twin double. All sums deposited in the twin double shall be held in a single pool entirely separate from all other pools, and the award or dividend to each winning participant shall be calculated subject to the provisions of this rule, as in a straight pool.
All twin double tickets shall be sold at properly designated windows and shall be clearly and immediately distinguishable from the daily double and other tickets sold.
All twin double tickets shall be sold only from automatic vending machines.

The sale of twin double tickets may not commence until after the completion of the second race of the day, unless special permission is obtained from a representative of the Commission. The twin double windows shall close and the machines shall be locked 5 minutes before the official post time of the first race of the first half of the twin double.

Each participant in the twin double shall designate his selections as the winners of the first half of the twin double races at the time he purchases his twin double ticket, and each twin double ticket shall show the selections made.

After the completion of the first half of the twin double races, each participant holding a ticket or tickets combining the winners of this half of the twin double shall, during the period while the twin double windows are open for this purpose, exchange his ticket or tickets for a ticket or tickets showing his selections as the winners of the second half of the twin double.
A twin double exchange ticket may not be issued except upon the surrender of a twin double ticket showing the winners of the first half of the twin double.

Twin double windows shall be opened for the issue only of twin double exchange tickets after the races comprising the first half have been completed and declared official and shall close at the official post time of the start of the second half of the races comprising the twin double.

Before post time of the second race of the second half of the twin double races, there shall be posted or announced over the loud speaker system the pay-off of each combination coupled with the winner of the first race of the second half of the twin double races. All such information shall be posted.

A winning twin double ticket not presented for exchange for a twin double exchange ticket within the period described in §H, above, may be presented for a refund of the purchase price (or award in the event that no participant selects the winner of the first race of the second half of the twin double races), after completion of the first race of the second half of the twin double. The aggregate purchase price of all twin double tickets so entitled to a refund shall be deducted from the gross twin double pool.

Inasmuch as the purpose of the twin double is to select winners of the first half and the second half of the twin double races, a participant who selects a horse which runs in but does not win a race is no longer eligible, unless no other participant has selected a winner of that race.
If a horse is scratched in the first race of the first half of the twin double, all tickets on the scratched horse shall be refunded, and the money refunded will be deducted from the gross pool.

If a horse is scratched in the second race of the first half of the twin double, after the running of the first race of the first half, all twin double tickets combining the scratched horse with the actual winner of the first race of the first half of the twin double shall be paid a price equivalent to that fraction of the net pool derived by dividing the net twin double pool (gross pool less commission) by the total number of tickets sold combining the winner of the first race of the first half of the twin double with all horses in the second race of the first half of the twin double. The quotient thus obtained shall constitute the consolation pay-off to be paid to holders of each ticket combining the winner of the first race of the first half with the scratched horse in the second race of the first half. The entire consolation pool (number of eligible tickets times the consolation price), plus the breakage, shall then be deducted from the net twin double pool. The remaining pool is the new net pool for the twin double.

If a horse is scratched in the first race of the second half of the twin double, during or after the exchange of tickets by holders of the first two winners, each ticket including the scratched horse in the first race of the second half shall be paid a price equivalent to that fraction of the net pool derived by dividing the net pool by the total number of exchanged tickets. The quotient thus obtained shall constitute the consolation pay-off to be paid to holders of tickets on the scratched horse. The entire consolation pool (number of eligible tickets times the consolation price), plus the breakage, shall be deducted from the net twin double pool to establish a new net pool.

If a horse is scratched from the second race of the second half of the twin double after the first race of the second half has been run, each ticket including the scratched horse and the winner of the first race of the second half shall be paid a price equivalent to that fraction of the net pool derived by dividing the net pool by the total number of tickets combining the winner of the first race of the second half. The quotient thus obtained shall constitute a consolation pay-off. The entire consolation pool (number of eligible tickets times the consolation price), plus breakage, shall then be deducted from the net pool. The remaining pool shall be the new net pool for the final pay-off for the twin double.

If no ticket is sold combining the winner of the first race and the winner of the second race of the first half of the twin double, the net pool shall then be apportioned between those having tickets, including the winner of the first race of the first half of the twin double and those having tickets including the winner of the second race of the first half of the twin double, and shall be calculated as a place pool. If this should happen, the twin double will terminate for that day.

If no ticket is sold including the winner of the first race of the first half of the twin double, then the entire net pool shall be paid to holders of tickets which include the winner of the second race of the first half of the twin double. If this should happen, the twin double will terminate for that day.

If no ticket is sold including the winner of the second race of the first half of the twin double, then the entire net pool shall be paid to holders of tickets which include the winner of the first race of the first half of the twin double. If this should happen, the twin double will terminate for that day.

If no exchange ticket includes the winner of the first race of the second half of the twin double, the entire net pool shall be distributed as a straight pool to all holders of exchanged tickets and winning combinations of the first half that had not been exchanged.

If no exchange ticket combines the winners of the first and second races of the second half of the twin double, then the entire net pool shall be distributed as a straight pool to holders of tickets including the winner of the first race of the second half of the twin double.

In the event of a dead heat in the first race of the first half of the twin double, all tickets combining both winners of the first race of the first half with the winner of the second race of the first half of the twin double shall be eligible for exchange.

In the event of a dead heat in the second race of the first half of the twin double, all tickets combining the winning or winners of the first race of the first half with the winners of the second race of the first half of the twin double shall be eligible for exchange.

In the event of a dead heat in the first race of the second half of the twin double, if there is no ticket combining either winner with the winner of the second race of the second half of the twin double, then the pay-off shall be distributed to holders of tickets on the winners of the first race of the second half of the twin double in the same manner as a place pool is calculated.

In the event of a dead heat in the second race of the second half of the twin double, the pay-off shall be distributed as a place pool to holders of tickets combining the winner of the first race of the second half with the winners of the second race of the second half of the twin double.
If, for any reason, the first race of the first half of the twin double is cancelled or declared "no race," full and complete refund shall be made of the twin double pool.

If, for any reason, the second race of the first half of the twin double is cancelled or declared "no race," the net pool shall be calculated as a straight pool and shall be distributed to holders of tickets combining the winner of the first race of the first half of the twin double with every horse in the second race of the first half of the twin double.

If, for any reason, the first race of the second half of the twin double is cancelled or declared "no race," the net pool shall be distributed as a straight pool to the holders of twin double exchange tickets and holders of winning twin double tickets not surrendered for exchange.

If, for any reason, the second race of the second half of the twin double is cancelled or declared "no race," the net pool shall be distributed as a straight pool among holders of exchange tickets designating the winner of the first race of the second half of the twin double.
Entries or field horses may not be allowed in any race included in the twin double, except by permission from a representative of the Commission.

In the event of a dead heat between a covered and an uncovered horse in the second race of the second half of the twin double, a consolation pay-off may not be made. Holders of tickets on the covered horse, representing the only winners of four consecutive races, shall share in the distribution of the twin double pool.
Each association shall either print in the daily program or prominently post at all areas where quinella wagering is conducted, the following conditions:
An exchange of tickets, after the purchaser has left the sales window, may not be made.
The quinella is not a parlay and has no connection with or relation to the "tote" betting. All tickets on the quinella will be calculated in an entirely separate pool.
Selections are to be made by program number and not by handicap rating number. Large numbers appearing on the quinella ticket are the program numbers of the horse.
All tickets should be retained until the result of the quinella has been posted.
All quinella tickets will be for the win and place combination only.
Quinella wagering is not permissible on races containing either a coupled entry or "field horses."

If any horse entered in a quinella race is scratched or excused by the judges after wagering has commenced or should any horse be prevented from racing because of failure of the arm of the starting gate to open, all tickets including the horse shall be deducted from the quinella pool and money refunded to the purchasers of tickets on the horse that is excused or prevented from racing.

If there are no tickets sold on the winning combination in a quinella race, all quinella tickets bearing the number of the individual win horse and all quinella tickets bearing the number of the individual place horse shall be deemed winning tickets and the payoff shall be calculated as a place pool.

If there are no tickets sold on the winning combination in a quinella race and should there be no quinella tickets sold bearing the number of the individual win horse, all quinella tickets bearing the number of the individual place horse shall be deemed winning tickets and the payoff shall be calculated as a win pool.

If there are no tickets sold on the winning combination in a quinella race, and should there be no quinella tickets sold bearing the number of the individual place horse, all quinella tickets bearing the number of the individual win horse shall be deemed winning tickets and the payoff shall be calculated as a win pool.

If there are no tickets sold on the winning combination in a quinella race, and should there be no quinella tickets sold bearing the number of the individual win horse, and should there be no quinella tickets sold bearing the number of the individual place horse, the quinella shall be deemed "no race," and all moneys in the quinella shall be promptly refunded.

If, after an official start is effected, only one horse finishes the quinella race, the total money is figured as a win pool, with those who have picked that one horse in the race participating in the pool.
If a two horse dead heat for win results in a quinella race, the two horses involved in the dead heat shall be the winners of the quinella race.

If a multiple dead heat for win results in a quinella race, all horses involved in the dead heat shall be winners of the quinella race and payoffs figured accordingly. For example, should numbers 1, 3, 5 and 7 dead heat for win, the winning quinella combinations would be 1-3, 1-5, 1-7, 3-5, 3-7, and 5-7. The net pool, after deducting the amounts wagered on the winning combinations, will be equally distributed in payoff calculations on the winning combinations.
If a two horse dead heat for place results in a quinella race, the total pool is calculated as a place pool.

If a multiple dead heat for place results in a quinella race, all combinations coupling the winning horse with the individual place horse shall be winners of the quinella race and payoffs calculated accordingly.

The exacta is a contract by the purchaser of a ticket combining two horses in a single race, selecting the two horses that will subsequently finish first and second in that race. Payment of the ticket shall be made only to the purchaser who has selected the same order of finish as officially posted.
The exacta is not a "parlay" and has no connection with or relation to the win, place and show betting and shall be calculated as an entirely separate pool.
In the event of an entry finishing first and second, the net exacta pool shall be distributed to holders of tickets combining the entry with the horse finishing third.

If a horse is scratched out of an exacta race, all exacta tickets combining the scratched horse with any other horse in that race shall be refunded and the money refunded shall be deducted from the gross pool.

If no ticket is sold selecting the winner and the second horse to finish one-two, in that order, the net pool shall be distributed as a place pool to the holders of tickets selecting the winner to finish first and the holders of tickets selecting the second horse to finish second.
If no ticket is sold that would require distribution of an exacta pool to a winner as above defined, the association shall make a complete and full refund of the exacta pool.

If two horses finish in a dead heat to win, the net pool shall be distributed as a place pool to the holders of tickets on the two winning combinations. For example: If 4 and 6 finish in a dead heat to win, holders of tickets on 6 and 4 as well as holders of tickets 4 and 6 will share in the net pool.

If two horses finish in a dead heat to place, the net pool shall be distributed as a place pool to the holders of tickets on the two winning combinations. For example: If 3 is the winner and 5 and 7 finish in a dead heat to place, holders of tickets combining 3 and 5, in that exact order, and holders of tickets combining 3 and 7, in that exact order, will share in the pool.

If there is a dead heat to win or a dead heat to place and no ticket has been sold on one of the winning combinations, the net pool shall be distributed to the holders of tickets on the other combination.

If there is a dead heat to place and no ticket has been sold combining the winner with either one of the two horses finishing in the dead heat, the holders of tickets selecting the winner to finish first and the holders of tickets selecting either one of the dead heat horses to finish second shall share in the net pool. The net pool shall be distributed as a place pool the winner shall receive one-half and the horses in the dead heat shall divide the remaining half proportionately between them.

The triple is a contract by the purchaser of a ticket combining three horses that will subsequently finish first, second and third in that race. Payment of the ticket shall be made only to the purchaser who has selected the same order of finish as officially posted.
The triple is not a parlay and has no connection with or relation to the win, place and show betting and shall be calculated as an entirely separate pool.
Repealed.

If no ticket is sold on the winning combination of a triple pool, the net pool shall be distributed to the holders of tickets selecting the win and place finishers in that order. If no ticket is sold combining the win and place finish, the net pool shall be distributed to the holders of tickets selecting the win and show horses. If no ticket is sold combining the win, place and show finishers, the net pool shall be distributed to the holders of tickets selecting the winner. If less than three horses finish, the payoff shall be made to holders of tickets selecting the finishing horses in order, ignoring the balance of the selection.
If no ticket is sold that would require distribution of the net triple pool to a winner as above defined, the association shall make a full refund of the triple pool.

In the event of a dead heat, all triple tickets selecting the correct order of finish, counting a horse in a dead heat as finishing in either position dead heated, shall be winning tickets. The payoff shall be calculated as a place pool by dividing the net triple pool by the total purchase price of winning tickets.

In the event of a scratch in the triple exchanges may not be made. All tickets which include the scratched horse are eliminated from further participation in the triple pool and shall be refunded. Refunds on key horse wheel tickets may be made after the triple race is official. Key horse wheel tickets shall be sold during the entire triple wagering period at the posted price used when triple wagering opens.
Coupled entries are permitted but fields are prohibited in triple races.

If the horses in a coupled entry finish in more than one of the first three positions, one or more of the horses, as necessary, finishing directly after the first three horses shall be used to complete a winning selection consisting of three different numbers.

Triple tickets shall be sold only by the licensee through pari-mutuel machines programmed to print all selections on one ticket. The design of triple tickets shall be clearly and immediately distinguishable from other pari-mutuel tickets. Resale of the tickets from one individual to another is prohibited and shall be grounds for ejection.
Each association shall print in heavy type in a conspicuous place in its printed program all the provisions of this regulation.

The Super Bet is a form of pari-mutuel wagering on three designated races. The bettor selects the two horses that will finish first and second in each of the first two designated races of the Super Bet, and the three horses that will finish first, second, and third in the third designated race of the Super Bet, in each case in the exact order of finish as officially posted.
The Super Bet pool shall be held entirely separate from all other pools, and may not be part of any exacta, triple, daily double, or other wagering pool. The Super Bet is not a parlay.
Repealed.
The three races which comprise the Super Bet shall be approved by the Commission and clearly designated in the program.
Super Bet tickets shall be clearly identified as such, so as to distinguish them from tickets on other wagering pools.
Coupled entries and fields are prohibited in the three designated Super Bet races.

If a dead heat or dead heats occur in any of the races of the Super Bet, all Super Bet tickets selecting the correct order of finish counting a horse in a dead heat as finishing in any position dead heated shall be winning tickets, and contrary to the usual practice, the aggregate winning tickets shall be divided into the net pool and be paid the same pay-off price.

Wagering for the Super Bet shall close at the same time that wagering is closed on the first designated race of the Super Bet. If a horse is scratched in a designated race of the Super Bet while wagering on the Super Bet is still open, wagers containing the scratched horse shall be deducted from the Super Bet pool and shall be refunded just as in other types of wagers. After the close of wagering on the Super Bet, refunds of wagers due to scratches may not be made until after prices have been declared official for the entire Super Bet. In the latter event, except as otherwise provided in §I, K, or L, refunds shall be made only for wagers selecting in each designated race of the Super Bet scratched horses and winning horses in the proper order but not any losing horses. For example, if the exact winning combination is 1-2, 1-2, 1-2-3, and the 4 horse in the designated second race was scratched, a wager of 1-2, 4-2, 1-2-3 would be eligible for a refund, but a wager of 1-2, 2-4, 1-2-3 would not be eligible for a refund.

If for any reason, including but not limited to weather conditions, less than all of the designated races of the Super Bet are cancelled or are not declared official, then all horses in the cancelled race or races that were selected on Super Bet tickets shall be considered winners for purposes of the Super Bet. If for any reason all of the designated races of the Super Bet are cancelled, then all pari-mutuel tickets that were issued for that performance shall be refunded and the Super Bet shall be cancelled for that performance. In all these instances, any contributions to the Super Bet pool from prior performances shall be carried over and included in the Super Bet pool for the next performance as prescribed in §J, below.

If there is no Super Bet ticket issued accurately selecting the officially declared winning combination in the exact order of finish in each of the three designated races of the Super Bet, then the net pool, after deduction of all applicable commissions and taxes under the laws of this State, shall be carried over and included with the net Super Bet pool at the next performance.

If the accumulated carry-over pool of the Super Bet has not been distributed before the closing day of the meeting in which the pool was generated, or if the Association invokes the provisions of §L, the net amount of the carry-over pool so remaining shall be distributed even if no Super Bet ticket is a winning ticket under A. In this event, the winning tickets shall be those combining on that performance the most consecutive finishers in the winning combination, starting with the winner of the first designated race of the Super Bet (for example, if the exact winning combination is 1-2, 1-2, 1-2-3, and the best ticket sold is 1-2, 1-2, 1-2-ALL). If there is a cancellation of the closing day's performance, the accumulated carry-over pool shall be carried over to the Harness Association next to operate that accepts Super Bet wagering. If the Harness Association next to operate does not accept Super Bet wagering, the accumulated carry-over pool shall be deposited in a Maryland bank in interest bearing form, and the accumulated pool together with all interest earned on it shall be carried over to the first day of the next racing meeting of the Harness Association accepting Super Bet wagering.

The Association accepting Super Bet wagering may elect, if there is an undistributed accumulated carry-over pool of the Super Bet, to declare a mandatory Super Bet distribution, provided it makes an announcement of its intention to do so at least 24 hours before the opening of Super Bet wagering for that performance. In this event, all of the Super Bet carry-over pool shall be distributed on this performance, even if no Super Bet ticket is a winning ticket under §A, in accordance with the provisions for determining a winning ticket under §K.

The Association may elect to guarantee a gross Super Bet pool (the accumulated carry-over pool plus gross Super Bet wagering on the current performance) by adding any shortfall from this guarantee to the accumulated carry-over pool, provided it makes announcement of its intention to do so before the opening of Super Bet wagering for that performance. Commissions or taxes may not be deducted from the added amount.

Sales of Super Bet tickets other than from pari-mutuel machines shall be deemed illegal and prohibited. Resale of Super Bet tickets from one individual to another is prohibited and shall be grounds for ejection.

The acceptance of the Super Bet ticket by an individual taking an issued ticket away from the window of the terminal from which it was issued shall constitute an acknowledgement by the bettor of the correctness of the ticket. Each purchaser of a Super Bet ticket agrees to be bound by the terms and provisions of this and all other applicable Commission regulations and by the laws of the State pertaining to pari-mutuel wagering. The Association, totalisator, and the State may not be liable to any person for a Super Bet ticket which is not:
A winning ticket in accordance with the provisions of this regulation; or
Delivered for any reason, including but not limited to:
Mechanical malfunction,
Electrical failure,
Machine locking, or
Other cause.
This regulation shall be prominently displayed in the betting area of each Association conducting a Super Bet program.
Definitions. In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated:
“Advisory Committee” means the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund Advisory Committee.
“Breeder” means the owner or, if leased, the lessee of the dam at the time of breeding.

“Conceived” means the impregnation of a dam, by means of natural or artificial insemination, by a Maryland stallion whose offspring meet the eligibility requirements for the Sires Stakes Program as provided under this regulation.
“Covered by a Maryland stallion” means to be bred to a Maryland stallion whose offspring meet the eligibility requirements for the Sire Stakes Program as provided under this regulation.
“Owner” means an individual or entity that owns or leases a horse or stallion eligible to participate in the Sires Stakes Program.
“USTA” means the United States Trotting Association.
Eligibility for Participation. For a horse to be eligible to participate in a race that is a part of the Sires Stakes Program, the horse shall:
Be registered with the Advisory Committee; and
Have had paid in the horse's behalf all of the applicable registration, sustaining, and declaration fees required under this regulation.
Eligibility for Registration.
A horse may be registered with the Advisory Committee if:
The horse was conceived from the fresh or frozen semen of a Maryland stallion; and
The Maryland stallion:
Is registered with the USTA;
Is registered with the Advisory Committee as a Maryland stallion;
Was at stud in Maryland for a full breeding season; and
Impregnated the dam during the breeding season the stallion was at stud in Maryland.
If a horse is the product of an embryo/ovum transfer, only a donor mare's first born foal each year, resulting from such a transfer, is eligible under this section.
Registration as a Maryland Stallion.
A stallion shall be registered by the Advisory Committee if the completed forms for the stallion’s registration are received by the Advisory Committee Administrator by:
December 1 of the year preceding the one for which the stallion is registered together with a $500 fee;
January 1 of the year for which the stallion is registered together with a $750 fee, if the stallion is not registered by the previous December 1; or
February 1 of the year for which the stallion is registered together with a $1,500 fee, if the stallion is not registered by the previous December 1.
Loss of Maryland Stallion Registration Status.
A stallion shall lose its status as a registered Maryland stallion if:
The stallion stands during the year anywhere other than in Maryland or in the southern hemisphere; or
The stallion leaves the breeding location in Maryland during the Maryland breeding season of February 15 through July 1 except as provided under §E(2) or (3) of this regulation.
A registered Maryland stallion may participate in racing during the breeding season provided the stallion is returned within 24 hours if the Administrator is notified and proper reports are filed.
When a Stallion May Be Moved.

A stallion may be moved to another location within the State from its registered breeding location during the breeding season for breeding purposes, provided the stallion is returned within 24 hours and the Standardbbred Race Fund Administrator is provided a detailed monthly report on the stallion’s movements, including the following:
The date on which the stallion was moved; and
The location to which the stallion was taken.
A stallion moved for emergency veterinarian care shall be returned when medically released and a detailed report is provided to the Administrator.
The offspring of a stallion which has lost its registration status shall remain eligible for this Program if the offspring was:
Out of a mare which was not owned or leased by the stallion owner; and
Otherwise eligible.

The owner of a stallion which has lost its status as a registered Maryland stallion is subject to the following penalty for each of its offspring that remain eligible for this program under §E(4) of this regulation:
$500 for a stallion with a registered stud fee of less than $500;
An amount equal to the stud fee of the stallion if the registered stud fee of the stallion is more than $500; or
$1,500 for a stallion with a private or undesignated stud fee.
Requirements of the Owner of a Registered Stallion.

The owner of a registered stallion shall submit a copy of the USTA Mares Bred report to the Advisory Committee Administrator not later than September 1 of the year for which the stallion is registered.
The Mares Bred report shall indicate:
Which broodmares were inseminated with transported semen, if any; and
The destination to which the semen had been transported for this purpose.
Failure to comply with the provisions of §F(1) and (2) of this regulation shall subject the owner of the stallion, for each month the owner is delinquent, to a penalty of:
$500 for a stallion with a registered stud fee of less than $500; or
$1,500 for a stallion with a private or undesignated stud fee.
Failure to comply with the provisions of §F(1) and (2) of this regulation by February 15 of the year following the year to be covered by the Mares Bred report shall:
Render any resultant foal out of a mare owned wholly or in part by the owner of the stallion ineligible to participate in the Sire Stakes Program for the year covered by the report; and
Subject the stallion owner, for each foal that remains eligible for the Sires Stakes Program, to a penalty of:
$500 for a stallion with a registered stud fee of less than $500; or
$1,500 for a stallion with a private, undesignated or stud fee over $500.
Payment of Penalties.
Penalties assessed against a stallion owner under this regulation shall be paid to the Advisory Committee Administrator.
The Advisory Committee shall consider the penalties paid by a stallion owner under this regulation as stallion registration fees to be used for the purpose of future Sires Stakes Program purses.
A stallion owner may not be allowed to participate in the Sires Stakes Program if the owner has not paid a penalty assessed under this regulation.
Appeal of Refusal to Register a Horse or Stallion.
An owner or breeder may appeal to the Commission from a refusal of the Advisory Committee to register a horse or stallion under this regulation.
The owner or breeder who takes the appeal has the burden of proving the eligibility of the horse or stallion.
The decision of the Commission is final.
Registration. Except as provided in §J of this regulation, in order to register a yearling, the Advisory Committee Administrator shall be provided on or before May 15 with a:
Completed form for the registration of the yearling; and
$40 registration fee.
Late or Incomplete Registration.

If a yearling was not registered in accordance with the provisions of §I of this regulation, the yearling shall be registered with the Advisory Committee Administrator if the following are received between May 16 of the yearling year and March 15 of the 2-year-old year:
A completed registration form;
A $500 late fee by December 31; or
A $1,000 late fee by March 15.
Sustaining Fees.
Except as provided in §K(2) of this regulation, the following sustaining fees are required by the following dates for the maintenance of a horse's eligibility:
First sustaining fee as a 2-year-old, $150 by March 15;
Second sustaining fee as a 2-year-old, $200 by May 15; and
Sustaining fee as a 3-year-old, $300 by February 15.
The second sustaining fee as a 2-year-old, due May 15, is optional and is required only to make the horse eligible to participate in the races provided by the Sires Stakes Program for 2-year-olds.

Except as provided under §K(2) of this regulation, a horse shall be disqualified from participation in any future races sponsored by this Program if there is a failure to make a timely payment of a fee under this section.
Time and Method of Payment.
To be timely, the appropriate fee shall be:
Delivered to the Advisory Committee Administrator by the designated due date; or
Mailed bearing a postmark which is on or before the due date.
If the due date for a payment falls on a weekend or a holiday observed in this State, the payment shall be timely if:
Delivered to the Advisory Committee Administrator by the next business day; or
Mailed bearing a postmark which is not later than the next business day.
Exceptions may not be made to the requirements of this section.
Declaration Fee.
A declaration fee, as prescribed in this regulation, is required to be made by the post time for the race into which the horse is declared.
Additional declaration fees are not required from a horse which participates in more than one preliminary race.
The declaration fee is $400.

The owner of the horse is responsible for the declaration fee, and, if the owner of the horse is not the declarer of the horse, the person making the declaration is also responsible for the declaration fee.
Eligibility to Start.
A horse, otherwise eligible to participate in this program, may not be declared in to start unless the horse has at least one satisfactory charted performance line at the time set for declaring in.
A satisfactory charted performance line is a performance line:
Credited to a horse after the horse starts from behind a starting gate in a qualifying or purse race within 45 days of the Sires Stakes Program race in which the horse is to participate; and

Which shows that the horse has completed the race without a break, other than a break caused by interference or broken equipment, at, or within, the following times according to the horse's age and gait:
A 2-second allowance to the minimum performance time shall be granted on any trotting event held before May 1.
Use of Fees.
All registration fees, sustaining fees, and penalties, less administrative costs, shall be added to the purse monies for this program.
All declaration fees shall be added to the purse of the final event for which the fees were paid.

Provisions may be made for the running of the following races at a distance of 1 mile, to be known as the Sires Stakes Program races, which shall be open only to those horses eligible to participate in the Sires Stakes Program:
2-year-old filly pace;
2-year-old colt pace;
2-year-old filly trot;
2-year-old colt trot;
3-year-old filly pace;
3-year-old colt pace;
3-year-old filly trot; and
3-year-old colt trot.
The various age, sex, and gait divisions established under §Q of this regulation may, from time to time, be eliminated by the Commission upon the recommendation of the Advisory Committee.
Each age, sex, and gait division, depending upon the availability of funds, may not be raced more than three times per year.

The purse amounts and the number of times per year each race is offered, including the number of preliminary races, for the races authorized under §Q of this regulation shall be determined by the Advisory Committee and approved by the Commission.
Breeder Awards.
An 8 percent Breeder Award, based upon the amount of the purse distributed in a “final”, shall be awarded to the dam of a horse, if the horse:
Receives purse monies from a "final" race provided for under §Q of this regulation; and
Meets the eligibility requirements set forth for registration in the Foaled Stakes Program under Regulation .43 of this chapter.

A 4 percent stallion award based upon the amount of the purse distributed in a “final”, shall be awarded to the sire of the horse provided the sire was a registered Maryland stallion at the time of conception.
The awards, as apportioned under §U(2) of this regulation, shall be paid to the:
Individual or entity who was the owner of record with the USTA of the dam and sire at the time the horse was bred; or
Lessee of the horse, rather than the owner, if the:
Dam or the sire, respectively, was leased at the time the breeding took place; and
Lease was on record with the USTA at that time.
Preliminary Events.
The number of preliminary events shall be as provided under §T of this regulation.

If more horses are declared to start in a preliminary event than can fit on the starting gate, the licensee holding the event shall schedule sufficient races and divide the horses by lot as equally as possible among the races scheduled.
Points shall be awarded to each horse finishing in a preliminary race in accordance with the following schedule:
In the event of a dead heat for any position, the horses involved in the dead heat for that position shall each be credited with the full number of points assigned to that position.
Final Events.
There shall be one final event for each category of race scheduled.
The number of horses allowed in a final event shall be limited to the horses which fit on the starting gate without a trailer.
Preference for participation in the final event shall be given to the horses with the most points earned in the preliminary events of the same category.
Not more than two horses with the next highest number of points from those drawn into the race may be listed as also eligibles.
Ties for participation under §W(3) and (4) of this regulation shall be determined by lot.
A horse may not participate in the final event if it did not earn a point in a preliminary event of the same category.
Post Positions. Post positions for all races shall be determined by lot.
Gait.
A horse's gait shall be specified and accompany each sustaining fee.
A change of a horse's specified gait may be made at the time the horse is declared into a race.
Any payments made before a change in the specified gait of a horse shall be credited to the races for the gait originally specified.
Time.
The time for starters to declare into a Sires Stakes Program race shall be the same as the time established by the race track for declaring into an overnight race.

If the race track schedules the time for drawing into an overnight race more than 5 days before the running of the races, a Sires Stakes Program race may not be drawn with these races, but shall be drawn at a time that is not more than 5 days before the scheduled running of the race.
Purse Distribution.
Purses for all races shall be divided:
50 percent to the winner;
25 percent to second;
12 percent to third;
8 percent to fourth; and
5 percent to fifth.
In the event fewer than five horses start, undistributed purse money shall be retained by the Race Fund.
Walkovers will be paid 50 percent of the advertised purse.

Unless the Commission eliminates the races for one of the age groups in accordance with §R of this regulation, the purse monies to be distributed each year on behalf of the Sire Stakes Program shall be divided equally between races for 2-year-olds and races for 3-year-olds.

Unless the Commission eliminates the races for one of the gaits in accordance with §R of this regulation, the purse monies in each age category shall be divided equally between races for trotters and races for pacers.
With the advice of the Advisory Committee the Commission may allow all the Sires Stakes Program races to be held at any race track in Maryland.

section.heading: Sire Stakes Program for 4 and 5 Year Olds.

para.text: Definitions.
In this regulation, the following terms have the same meanings as provided in Regulation .53 of this chapter.
Terms Defined.
"Advisory Committee";
"Breeder";
"Owner"; and
"USTA".
Eligibility for Participation. For a horse to be eligible to participate in a race that is a part of the Sires Stakes Program for 4 and 5-Year-Olds, the horse shall:
Have been nominated as a yearling to the Sire Stakes Program; and
Be registered with the Advisory Committee Administrator by February 15 as a 4-year-old or a 5- year- old to race that year.
Sustaining Fees.
Except as provided in §C(2) of this regulation, the following sustaining fees are required by the following dates for the maintenance of a horse's eligibility:
A sustaining fee as a 4-year-old, $120 and a completed sustaining form by February 15 of that year; or
A sustaining fee as a 5-year-old, $120 and a completed sustaining form by February 15 of that year.
If the March 15 2-year-old payment and the February 15 3-year-old payment were made, no sustaining fee is due.

Except as provided under §C(2) of this regulation, a horse shall be disqualified from participation in any races during the current year sponsored by this Program if there is a failure to make a timely payment of a fee under this section.
Time and Method of Payment.
To be timely, the appropriate fee shall be:
Delivered to the Advisory Committee Administrator by the designated due date; or
Mailed bearing a postmark which is on or before the due date.
If the due date for a payment falls on a weekend or a holiday observed in this State, the payment shall be timely if:
Delivered to the Advisory Committee Administrator by the next business day; or
Mailed bearing a postmark which is not later than the next business day.
Exceptions may not be made to the requirements of this section.
Declaration Fee.
A declaration fee, as prescribed in this regulation, is required to be made by the post time for the race into which the horse is declared.
The declaration fee is $100.

The owner of the horse is responsible for the declaration fee, and, if the owner of the horse is not the declarer of the horse, the person making the declaration is also responsible for the declaration fee.
Eligibility to Start.
A horse, otherwise eligible to participate in this program, may not be declared in to start unless the horse has at least one satisfactory charted performance line at the time set for declaring in.
A satisfactory charted performance line is a performance line:

Credited to a horse after the horse starts from behind a starting gate in a qualifying or purse race within 45 days of the Sires Stakes Program for 4 and 5 Year-Olds race in which the horse is to participate; and

Which shows that the horse has completed the race without a break, other than a break caused by interference or broken equipment, at, or within, the following times according to the horse's age and gait:
For events conducted on a 5/8 mile track:
For events conducted on a 1/2 mile track:
Use of Fees.
All sustaining fees, less administrative costs, shall be added to the purse monies for this program.
All declaration fees shall be added to the purse of the event for which the fees were paid.
Types of Races.

Provisions may be made for the running of the following races at a distance of 1 mile, to be known as the Sires Stakes Program for 4 and 5-Year-Olds, which shall be open only to those horses eligible to participate in the Sires Stakes Program for 4 and 5-Year-Olds:
4- and 5-year-old pace for colts and fillies; and
4- and 5-year-old trot for colts and fillies.
Upon the recommendation of the Advisory Committee, the races provided for in §I(1)(a) and (b) of this regulation may be separated into races for colts only and fillies only.

If more horses are declared to start in an event than can fit on the starting gate, the licensee holding the event shall split the event and divide the purse equally, except the declaration fees shall be allocated based on the number of horses in each division.
The various age, sex, and gait divisions established under §I of this regulation may, from time to time, be eliminated by the Commission upon the recommendation of the Advisory Committee.
Each age, sex, and gait division, depending upon the availability of funds, may not be raced more than three times per year.

The purse amounts and the number of times per year each race is offered for the races authorized under §I of this regulation shall be determined by the Advisory Committee and approved by the Commission.
Breeder Awards.
10 percent Breeder Award, based upon the amount of the purse distributed, shall be divided between the dam and sire of a horse, if the horse:
Receives purse monies from a race provided for under §I of this regulation; and

Meets the applicable eligibility requirements set forth for registration in the Foaled Stakes Program under Regulation .43 of this chapter, or in the Sire Stakes Program under Regulation .53 of this chapter.
Of the 10 percent awarded under §N(1) of this regulation:
8 percent shall be awarded to the dam of the horse; and
2 percent shall be awarded to the sire of the horse.
The awards, as apportioned under §N(2) of this regulation, shall be paid to the:
Individual or entity who was the owner of record with the USTA of the dam and sire at the time the horse was bred; or
Lessee of the horse, rather than the owner, if the:
Dam or the sire, respectively, was leased at the time the breeding took place; and
Lease was on record with the USTA at that time.
Post positions for all races shall be determined by lot.
Gait.
A horse's gait shall be specified and accompany each sustaining fee.
A change of a horse's specified gait may be made at the time the horse is declared into a race.
Any payments made before a change in the specified gait of a horse shall be credited to the races for the gait originally specified.
Time.
The time for starters to declare into a Sires Stakes Program for 4 and 5-Year-Olds race shall be the same as the time established by the race track for declaring into an overnight race.

If the race track schedules the time for drawing into an overnight race more than 5 days before the running of the races, a Sires Stakes Program for 4 and 5-Year-Olds race may not be drawn with these races, but shall be drawn at a time that is not more than 5 days before the scheduled running of the race.
Purse Distribution.
The purse in each race shall be divided in the following manner:
50 percent, 25 percent, 12 percent, 8 percent, and 5 percent to the first five finishers, respectively, if five or more horses finish;
50 percent, 25 percent, 15 percent, and 10 percent to the first four finishers, respectively, if only four horses finish;
55 percent, 30 percent, and 15 percent to the first three finishers, respectively, if only three horses finish;
65 percent and 35 percent to the first two finishers, respectively, if only two horses finish; or
65 percent to the finisher and 35 percent remains with the gait, if only one horse finishes.
Unless the Commission eliminates the races for one of the gaits in accordance with §K of this regulation, the purse monies shall be divided equally between races for trotters and races for pacers.
With the advice of the Advisory Committee, the Commission may allow the entire Sires Stakes Program for 4 and 5-Year-Olds races to be held at any race track in Maryland.

section.heading: Payments to Maryland Standardbred Race Fund.

para.text: For each harness track meet, any moneys allocated to the Maryland Standardbred Race Fund and required to be paid to the Maryland Racing Commission by the licensee, will be paid to the Commission within 5 days after the close of the meet, or the outstanding balance will after that bear interest at the prime rate, as presently published in the Wall Street Journal under Money Rates for the publication date of the 5th day, or the immediately preceding publication date if the 5th day is not a publication date, on a per diem basis until available funds are paid the Commission for the outstanding amount due, including interest.
In this chapter, "meet" means a specified period of consecutive days when an association is licensed by the Commission to conduct racing.
The Standardbred Race Fund Advisory Committee shall select an administrator to supervise the daily operation of the Standardbred Race Fund.
The Administrator selected by the Standardbred Fund Advisory Committee shall be appointed by, and serve at the pleasure of, the Commission.

The salary and benefits of the Administrator shall be established by the Commission and, together with the other reasonable expenses incurred in the administration of the Standardbred Race Fund, shall be paid from the monies that inure to the Standardbred Race Fund.

The Pick Six is a form of pari-mutuel wagering. Each bettor selects the first horse in each of six consecutive races designated as the Pick Six races by the Association. The principle of a Pick Six is, in effect, a contract by the purchaser of a Pick Six ticket to select the winners of each of the six races designated as the Pick Six.

The Pick Six pool shall be held entirely separate from all other pools and is not part of a daily double, exacta, trifecta, or other wagering pool. The Pick Six pool is a pool in which the bettor is required to select six consecutive winning horses and is not a parlay.
Repealed.
Races in which Pick Six pools shall be conducted shall be approved by the Maryland Racing Commission and clearly designated in the program.
The design of Pick Six tickets shall be clearly and immediately distinguished from other pari-mutuel tickets with the identification "Pick 6" printed on the ticket.
The Pick Six pari-mutuel pool shall be calculated as follows:

Seventy-five percent of the net amount in the pari-mutuel pool subject to distribution among winning ticket holders shall be distributed among the holders of pari-mutuel tickets which correctly designate the official winner in each of the six races comprising the Pick Six. The remaining undistributed 25 percent of the net pool shall be distributed among the holders of pari-mutuel tickets which correctly designate the most winning selections less than the six winning selections described above.

If there is no pari-mutuel ticket held which correctly designates the winner of all races comprising the Pick Six, 75 percent of that racing date's net amount available for distribution shall be carried over and included in the Pick Six pool requiring six winning selections, at the next performance.

If a Pick Six ticket designates as a selection to win in any one or more of the contests comprising the Pick Six, a single wagering interest which is scratched, excused or determined by the stewards to be a non-starter in the race, the actual favorite, as evidenced by the amounts wagered in the win pool at the time of the start, will be substituted for the non-starting selection for all purposes including pool calculations and payoffs, provided further that if the win pool for two or more favorites is identical, the selection shall be the lowest program number substituted for the non-starting selection.

The cancellation of one or more contests comprising the Pick Six in any performance shall result in that day's net pool being fully distributed to the individuals holding the most winners on that day's performance. If three or more of the six contests comprising the Pick Six are officially cancelled or declared as no contest, all pari- mutuel tickets on the Pick Six for that performance shall be refunded, and the Pick Six shall be cancelled for that performance. Any contributions to the Pick Six pool from prior performances will remain in the Pick Six pool to be carried over and included in the Pick Six pool for the next performance as prescribed in §F(2), above.

If the accumulated Pick Six has not been distributed prior to the closing day of the meeting in which the Pick Six pool was generated, the accumulated Pick Six pool and the net amount in the Best of Six pool, subject to distribution among winning ticket holders, shall be distributed among closing day holders of Pick Six tickets which correctly designate the most official winners of the six contests comprising the closing day Pick Six. Should there be a cancellation of the final day's card, or if the final day of Pick Six pool is cancelled, the contributions shall be transferred to the next harness track to operate.

Those horses constituting an entry or a field as defined within the regulations of the Maryland Racing Commission shall race in any Pick Six race as a single wagering interest for the purpose of the Pick Six race pari-mutuel pool calculations and payouts to the public. A scratch, after wagering has begun, of any part of any entry or field selection in such a race shall be of no effect with respect to the status of this entry or field, or both, as a viable wagering interest.

If, for any reason, any race or races of a Pick Six program is cancelled and declared "No Race", the Pick Six pool shall be distributed to the holders of the most winning selections of the remaining races pursuant to §F. If the judges cancel or declare "No Race" in three or more of the Pick Six races for any given date, all pari-mutuel tickets for that Pick Six pool shall be refunded and the Pick Six cancelled for that day.

If there is a dead-heat for win between two or more horses in any Pick Six race, all these horses in the dead-heat for win shall be considered as the winning horse in the race for the purpose of distributing the Pick Six pari-mutuel pool.

A person may not disclose the number of tickets sold in the Pick Six pool or the number or amount of tickets selecting winners of Pick Six races before the time the judges have declared the last Pick Six race on any given date "official".
A pari-mutuel ticket for the Pick Six pool may not be sold, exchanged, or cancelled after the time of the closing of wagering in the first of the six races comprising the Pick Six.

A validly issued Pick Six ticket timely surrendered to the association by the legal holder of it shall be the only evidence of a person's participation in the Pick Six pari-mutuel pool. The acceptance of a Pick Six ticket by taking an issued ticket away from the window or terminal from which it is purchased shall constitute an acknowledgement by the purchaser of the correctness of the ticket, and each purchaser of a Pick Six ticket agrees to be bound by the terms and provisions of this and all other applicable Commission rules and regulations and by the laws of the State pertaining to pari-mutuel wagering. The association, totalisator company, and the State may not be liable to a person for a ticket which is not a winning ticket in accordance with the provisions of this rule. The association, totalisator company, and the State may not be liable to a person for a Pick Six ticket not delivered for any reason, including but not limited to mechanical malfunction, electrical failure, machine locking, or other cause.
This rule shall be prominently displayed throughout the betting area of each association conducting a Pick Six program.
The Twin Trifecta is a type of bet in which:
A bettor initially selects three different betting interests to finish first, second, and third in that exact order in the first race of two designated races; and

For each successful minimum bet on the first of the two designated races of the Twin Trifecta, a bettor is entitled to one opportunity to select three different betting interests to finish first, second, and third in that exact order in the second race.
A successful minimum bet on the first race of the Twin Trifecta is the only means by which a bettor may participate under §A(2) of this regulation.
Repealed.
The betting pool created under §A of this regulation shall be refunded if:

For any reason, the number of betting interests for either the first race or the second race of the Twin Trifecta is reduced to less than seven before betting is opened for the first race of this bet;
The first race of the two designated races is cancelled or declared no race; or
No bet on the first race of the two designated races contains a successful selection as set forth in §§E(1)(a) or J of this regulation.

Unless there is a refund of the betting pool as set forth in §D of this regulation, or a racing association elects to employ the option specified under §G of this regulation, the net pool created by the Twin Trifecta bets shall be divided into two pools, where:
One pool shall be assigned to the first race and shall be distributed among those bets which contain the:
Betting interests finishing first, second, and third in that exact order in the first race of the two designated races; or
Most correct betting interests as set forth in §J of this regulation if no bet satisfies §E(1)(a) of this regulation; and
The other pool shall be assigned to the second race of the two designated races and shall be:
Distributed, along with any carry over, among those bets which contain the betting interests finishing first, second, and third in that exact order in the second race of the two designated races;

Distributed among those bets which contain the betting interests which finished first, second, and third in that exact order in the first race of the two designated races if the second race of the two designated races is cancelled or declared no race;

Carried over and added to the same type of pool on the next program of the race meeting if no bet on the day's program contains the betting interests finishing first, second, and third in that exact order in the second race of the two designated races; or
Distributed, along with any carry over, among those bets which contain the most correct betting interests, as set forth in §J of this regulation, in the second race of the two designated races, if:
No bet contains all the correct selections, and
The racing association has given prior notice that there will be a mandatory distribution of the carry over.
The formula for allocating the net pool among the two pools created under §E of this regulation shall be:
Established by the racing association; and
Maintained, as established, until the pool assigned to the second race of the two designated races, including the carry over pool, if any, has been distributed.
Entire Net Pool Assigned to Second Race of Twin Trifecta.
Upon giving prior notice, a racing association may conduct a Twin Trifecta by which the entire net pool created by the Twin Trifecta bets is:
Assigned to the second race of the Twin Trifecta; and
Distributed in accordance with the provisions of §E(2) of this regulation.

If the association elects to employ the provisions of §G(1) of this regulation, the association shall continue to employ these provisions until the pool created by employing these provisions, including the carry over pool, if any, has been distributed.
The will pay on the pools created in §E of this regulation and the pool created in §G of this regulation shall be calculated in the following manner:
Multiply the total number of successful bets at the minimum bet level in the pool by the minimum bet established under §C of this regulation;
Divide the total amount in the pool by the answer to §H(1) of this regulation;
Reduce the answer to §H(2) of this regulation to the next lowest multiple of 10 cents;
Multiply the answer to §H(3) of this regulation by the established minimum bet;
The answer to §H(4) of this regulation becomes the will pay for a minimum bet.

If the answer to §H(2) of this regulation is less than $1.10, §H(2) of this regulation shall be disregarded, and $1.05 shall be substituted for the answer obtained from the calculation in §H(3) of this regulation.

If no bet contains the betting interests finishing first, second, and third in that exact order in the first race of the two designated races, or a distribution of the pool assigned to the second race of the two designated races is required by the provisions of §E(2)(d) of this regulation, the distribution of a pool assigned to these races shall be based:
On bets which contain the betting interests finishing first and second in that exact order; and
If there is no bet that is in accordance with §J(1) of this regulation, on bets which contain the betting interest finishing first, selected in that position.
Dead Heat.

If a dead heat or heats occur for any of the first three positions in either of the two designated races, a horse in a dead heat shall be considered as finishing in any position for which it dead heated.

In the event of a dead heat as described in §K(1) of this regulation, contrary to the usual practice, the aggregate number of winning tickets shall be used to calculate the will pay without regard to the number of selections containing a betting interest in one position or the other.
Scratches.
If a betting interest in the first race of a Twin Trifecta is scratched, all issued tickets which include the scratched betting interest shall be refunded.
If a betting interest in the second race of a Twin Trifecta is scratched, the judges shall act as follows:

If there are more than 5 minutes to post remaining, as displayed on the infield tote board, the judges shall declare, by means of a public address announcement, that tickets which include the scratched betting interest may be exchanged before the running of the race; or

If there are 5 minutes or less to post remaining, as displayed on the infield tote board, the judges shall determine if there are tickets issued which contain the scratched betting interest and act as follows:
If there are no tickets, the judges shall take no further action, or

If there are tickets, the judges shall declare, by means of a public address announcement, that the bets on the second of the two designated races are cancelled, and the pool allocated to the second race of the Twin Trifecta from that day only, not including any carry over, shall be distributed among those bets which contain the betting interests finishing first, second, and third in that exact order in the first race of the two designated races.

If betting on the first race of the two designated races of a Twin Trifecta has started, and the number of betting interests for either the first or second race of the two designated races is reduced to less than seven, the racing association shall elect, in its sole and final discretion, to:
Refund the bets; or
Continue to offer this type of bet.

If, after the first race of the two designated races has been run, and the second race of the two designated races has less than seven betting interests, the racing association shall elect, in its sole and final discretion, to:
Continue to offer this type of bet; or

Cancel this type of bet for the day and distribute the pool from this day only, not including any carry over, among those bets which contain the betting interests finishing first, second, and third in that exact order in the first race of the two designated races.
Prohibitions. The following acts are prohibited:
Sales of tickets on this bet by any means other than through pari-mutuel machines; and
Disclosure of the number of tickets eligible for exchange on the second of the two designated races.
If, at the end of the race meeting, the carry over pool has not been distributed in accordance with §E(2)(a) or (d) of this regulation, this pool shall be:
Placed in an interest-bearing escrow account, with the information on this account being furnished to the Commission; and
Carried over, with the accumulated interest, to a similar pool and offered for distribution on the first day of the next race meeting of the racing association at which the pool was generated.
Coupled entries and fields are permitted in the races on which this bet is offered.

If the horses in a coupled entry or the horses in a field finish in more than one of the first three positions, one or more of the horses, as necessary, finishing directly after the first three horses shall be used to complete a winning bet consisting of three different betting interests.
This regulation shall be prominently displayed in the betting area of a racing association offering this type of bet.
The Superfecta is a type of bet in which a bettor must select four different betting interests to finish first, second, third, and fourth in that exact order.

If there was no bet issued which selected the first four betting interests in the exact order and the association has not provided for a carryover under §I of this regulation or provided for the distribution of a carryover under §J of this regulation, the net pool from this bet shall be distributed, in the following order of precedence, among those bets which selected the betting interests which finished:
First, second, and third in that exact order;
First and second in that exact order, if there is no bet that complies with §C(1) of this regulation; or
First, if there is no bet that complies with §B(1) or (2) of this regulation.

If fewer than four betting interests finish the race, the net pool, not including any carryover, shall be distributed among the bets which selected the betting interests finishing the race in the exact order of the finish.
Pay Off.

The pay off on winning bets shall be calculated as established for a win bet in accordance with Regulation .45W(1) of this chapter unless there is a dead heat for one or more of the first four positions.
If there is a dead heat for one or more of the first four positions:
The betting interests dead heated shall be counted as finishing in all of the places encompassed by the dead heat; and
The pay off shall be calculated as established for a place or show pool in accordance with Regulation .45W(2) or (3) of this chapter, whichever is applicable.
The betting pool created under §A of this regulation, not including any carryover, shall be refunded if, for any reason:
No bet made qualifies for a payoff under §B or C of this regulation; or
The judges declare the race a "no contest".
The Superfecta may not be offered on a race which contains a field.
If the horses in a coupled entry finish in more than one of the first four positions, one or more of the horses, as necessary, finishing directly after the first four horses shall be:
Used to complete a winning selection consisting of four different numbers; and
Assigned the positions behind those horses which have been advanced due to the coupled entry finishing in more than one of the first four positions.
If a Superfecta bet contains a betting interest which is scratched, the bet shall be refunded.

If, before accepting bets on a race for which Superfecta betting is offered, the association announces that a certain percentage of the Superfecta net pool will be carried over if no bet selects the first four finishers in exact order:
The percentage carried over shall be distributed proportionately among those bets which select the first four finishers in exact order the next time the bet is offered; and
The remainder of the pool shall be distributed in accordance with §C of this regulation.

If the association has announced before accepting bets on the race that it will distribute the amount carried over from prior races, and no bet selects the first four finishers in exact order, the association shall distribute the carryover using the distribution provisions under §B of this regulation, unless the provisions of §E of this regulation apply.

The Pick (n) is a type of bet encompassing four or more races, the exact number of races being determined by the number substituted for (n), in which a bettor selects a betting interest to finish not lower than the position specified for this bet by the racing association for each of the races comprising the bet.
Repealed.
A Pick (n) bet shall be refunded if:
For any reason, 50 percent or more of the races scheduled as a part of this bet are cancelled or declared a "no contest"; or
No bet qualifies for a pay off under the provisions of §D, E, or F(1) of this regulation, and the provisions of §H of this regulation have not been invoked.

If one or more of the races scheduled as part of the Pick (n) bet, but fewer than the number specified under §C(1) of this regulation, are cancelled or declared a "no contest", the net pool on the bet from that day only shall be distributed, on a pari-mutuel basis, among the bets which contain the most correct selections for the races which were run.

Except as provided in §C or D of this regulation, the net pool created under a Pick (n) bet, along with any carryover from previous pools of the same type of bet, shall be distributed on a pari-mutuel basis among those bets which contain:
All the correct selections; or
The most correct selections if:
No bet contains all the correct selections, and
The racing association has given prior notice that there will be a mandatory distribution of the carryover.

If no bet contains all the correct selections in accordance with §E(1) of this regulation, and §E(2) of this regulation has not been invoked, the net pool created under a Pick (n) bet shall be divided into two pools, where:
One pool shall be distributed among those bets which contain the most correct selections; and
The other pool shall be carried over to the next program to offer this type of bet.
The formula for allocating the net pool among the two pools created under §F of this regulation shall be:
Established by the racing association; and
Maintained as established, until:
A bet contains all the correct selections, or
The carryover pool is distributed in accordance with the provisions of §E(2) of this regulation.
Entire Net Pool Assigned to Bets Containing All the Correct Selections.
Upon giving prior notice, a racing association may conduct a Pick (n) for which the entire net pool created by this bet may only be distributed to bets which contain all the correct selections.

If the racing association elects to employ the provisions of §H(1) of this regulation, the association shall continue to employ these provisions until the pool created by employing these provisions, including the carryover pool, if any, has been distributed.

Dead Heat. If a dead heat or heats occur involving horses finishing in, or higher than, any of the places for which this bet is offered, a horse in a dead heat shall be considered as finishing in the position for which it dead heated.

If there is more than one combination of winning bets, the aggregate dollars bet on the winning combinations shall be used to calculate the will pay without regard to the amount bet on one winning combination in relation to the amount bet on another winning combination.
Scratches. If a betting interest is scratched, excused, or determined by the judges to be a nonstarter:

The actual favorite, as evidenced by the amounts bet in the win pool when betting on the race in which the scratched betting interest was to participate is closed, shall be substituted for that betting interest; or

The favorite with the lowest program number shall be substituted for the scratched betting interest if the amount bet in the win pool is identical on two or more favorites when betting on the race is closed.
A driver challenge event is one in which the:
Racing association:
Designates the specific races on a racing program that will comprise the event; and
Assigns a number to each of the drivers participating in these races;
Number of runners scheduled to participate in each race comprising the event is:
The same; and
No more than nine;
Same drivers are scheduled to drive in each race comprising the event; and
Selection of the number assigned to a driver automatically selects the horses scheduled to be driven by that driver in each race comprising the driver challenge event.
A racing association conducting a driver challenge event may offer any type of bet on this series of races that is authorized by this chapter for a single race.
Points.
Points shall be awarded to each betting interest according to the finish of the horses in each race comprising the driver challenge event, as follows:
14 points for a first place finisher;
9 points for a second place finisher;
7 points for a third place finisher; and

The points awarded for each subsequent finisher after the finisher under §C(1)(c) of this regulation shall decrease by one point from the points awarded to the preceding finisher, ending at one point for the ninth place finisher.

If there is a dead heat for any position in one or more of the races comprising this event, the points for the position dead-heated and the subsequent position or positions, as appropriate, shall be aggregated and then allocated proportionately for the horses involved in the dead heat.
If a horse is scratched, declared a nonstarter in a race, or the race is called "No Contest", the betting interests involved shall be awarded one point for that race.
After the last race of the driver challenge event, the points earned by each betting interest shall be totaled and the betting interest with the:
Highest number of points shall be considered to have finished first;
Second highest number of points shall be considered to have finished second;
Third highest number of points shall be considered to have finished third; and
All subsequent places shall be awarded accordingly.
Any ties for the places determined under §C(4) of this regulation shall be broken by awarding the place for which the betting interests tied to the betting interest with the greatest number of:
First place finishes;
Second place finishes, if a tie still exists after applying the provisions of §C(5)(a) of this regulation; and
Finishers at the next lower finishing position, down to nine, if a tie still exists after applying the provisions of §C(5)(a) and (b) of this regulation.
If, at the end of the process described under §C(5) of this regulation, the tie is not broken, the betting interests tied shall be considered to have finished in a dead heat.

The Ocean High Five is a contract by the purchaser of a ticket combining five horses to finish first, second, third, fourth, and fifth, in that specific order, in a race on which Ocean High Five wagering is offered. Payment of the ticket shall be made only to the purchaser who has selected the same order of finish as officially posted.
